## **Basic Statistics Reference Table**

<br>

<center>

| **Inference for ...** |  | **Mathematical Notations** |
|:---:|:---:|---|
| **One Proportion** | Relevant Variables | One two-level categorical |
|  | Population Parameters | $p \longrightarrow$ population proportion<br><br>$p_0 \longrightarrow$ null value |
|  | Sample Statistics | $\hat{p} \longrightarrow$ population proportion (point estimate) |
|  | Theoretical Conditions | - Independent samples<br>- Success-failure: $np \ge 10$ and $n(1-p) \ge 10$ |
|  | Hypothesis Testing | $H_0: p = p_0 \longrightarrow$ null hypothesis<br><br>$H_A: p > p_0, p < p_0, \text{ or } p \ne p_0 \longrightarrow$ alternative hypothesis<br><br>$\alpha \longrightarrow$ significance level (type I error rate)<br><br>$SE_{p_0} = \sqrt{\frac{p_0(1-p_0)}{n}} \longrightarrow$ standard error<br><br>$z = \frac{\hat{p}-p_0}{SE_{p_0}} \longrightarrow$ test statistic (z-score)<br><br>$\text{p-value} = \begin{cases} P(Z > z) \text{ or } P(Z < z) & \longrightarrow \text{ one-sided test for } > \text{ or } <, \\ 2*P(Z > z) & \longrightarrow \text{ two-sided test for } \ne \end{cases}$ |
|  | Confidence Interval | $SE_{\hat{p}} = \sqrt{\frac{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}{n}} \longrightarrow$ standard error<br><br>$ME = z^* SE_{\hat{p}} \longrightarrow$ margin of error<br><br>$cl = 1-\alpha \longrightarrow$ confidence level<br><br>$z^* \longrightarrow$ critical value at $cl$ confidence level<br><br>$\hat{p} \pm ME = (\hat{p}-ME,\hat{p}+ME) \longrightarrow$ interval |
| **Difference of Two Proportions** | Relevant Variables | Two two-level categorical |
|  | Population Parameters | $p_a \longrightarrow$ population proportion for group a<br><br>$p_b \longrightarrow$ population proportion for group b<br><br>$p_0 = 0 \longrightarrow$ null value |
|  | Sample Statistics | $\hat{p}_a \longrightarrow$ sample proportion (point estimate) for group a<br><br>$\hat{p}_b \longrightarrow$ sample proportion (point estimate) for group b |
|  | Theoretical Conditions |  |
|  | Hypothesis Testing |  |
|  | Confidence Interval |  |

</center>

## **Common Mathematical Symbols and their LaTeX Syntax in RMarkdown**

<br>

-   Equal sign: `$=$` will render as $=$.

-   Not equal sign: `$\ne$` will render as $\ne$.

-   Lesser than sign: `$<$` will render as $<$.

-   Greater than sign: `$<$` will render as $>$.

-   Lesser than or equal to sign: `$\le$` will render as $\le$.

-   Greater than or equal to sign: `$\ge$` will render as $\ge$.

-   Using hats: `$\hat{p}$` will render as $\hat{p}$.

-   Using bars: `$\bar{x}$` will render as $\bar{x}$.

-   Greek lowercase letter mu: `$\mu$` will render as $\mu$.

-   Greek lowercase letter beta: `$\beta$` will render as $\beta$.

-   The letter p: `$p$` will render as $p$.

-   Subscripting: `$p_{A}$` will render as $p_{A}$.

-   Set union: `$\cup$` will render as $\cup$.

-   Set intersection: `$\cap$` will render as $\cap$.

-   Summation Notation: `$\sum_{i=0}^k$` will render as $\sum_{i=0}^k$.

-   Infinity: `$\infty$` will render as $\infty$.
